Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Architectural and Algorithmic Solutions for Large Scale PEV Integration into Power Grids

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project designs algorithms for the integration of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PEVs) into the power grid. Specifically, the project will formulate and solve optimization problems critical to various entities in the PEV ecosystem -- PEV owners, commercial charging station owners, aggregators, and distribution companies -- at the distribution / retail level. Charging at both commercial charging stations and at residences will be considered, for both the case when PEVs only function as loads, and the case when they can also function as sources, equipped with vehicle-to-home (V2H) or vehicle-to-grid (V2G) energy reinjection capability. The focus of the project is on distributed decision making by various individual players to achieve analytical system-level performance guarantees.

Electrification of the transportation market offers revenue growth for utility companies and automobile manufacturers, lower operational costs for consumers, and benefits to the environment. By addressing problems that will arise as PEVs impose extra load on the grid, and by solving challenges that currently impede the use of PEVs as distributed storage resources, this research will directly impact the society. The design principles gained will also be applicable to other cyber-physical infrastructural systems. A close collaboration with industrial partners will ground the research in real problems and ensure quick dissemination of results to the marketplace. A strong educational component will integrate the proposed research into the classroom to allow better training of both undergraduate and graduate students. The details of the project will be provided at http://ee.nd.edu/faculty/vgupta/research/funding/cps_pev.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to design algorithms and architectures for large scale integration of electrical vehicles (EVs) in power grids. In particular three modes of EV integration were explored. In the first mode, EVs were assumed not to have the capability to feed energy back in either vehicle to home (V2H) or vehicle to grid (V2G) modes. Thus, the vehicles served mostly as a spatio-temporal load on the grid. The main insight here was that relying on residential charging alone can severely constrain driving patterns. Charging at commercial stations, office buildings, parking lots, shopping malls and so on will be required for any significant PEV penetration. Two main outcomes were a set of tools for the EV driver to identify remaining driving range based on accurate GIS based models and algorithms to design the interactions between the station owner and the electricity suppliers (aggregators and distribution companies) on one hand, and the station owner and the PEV owners on the other. The first outcome also led to development of an app that is publicly available while the second outcome led to charging scheduling algorithms, possible contracts that the charging station owners can offer and analyze the impact on the power grids. The problems of how charging stations can take advantage of power generation from renewable sources, and the problem of optimal charging station location and pricing were also solved.

In the second mode, EVs were assumed to be charged at residences but without V2H and V2G capabilities. The nature of residential charging is quite different than commercial charging due to reasons such as the availability of the PEVs to charge; the ability of the household energy managers to coordinate the PEVs charging with all the other household loads and the charging rates allowed for the PEVs under residential contracts with the electric utilities. PEVs are expected to be parked at home during night hours, when electricity prices are low, and intermittently during day hours when electricity prices are high. For the distribution company, this provides an opportunity to use demand response mechanisms to obtain a favorable load profile, or other ancillary services. The effect of the additional load on the physical infrastructure of the distribution level should also be considered. Effects of latencies or errors in information flow, possibility of aggregators mediating this interaction, and design of contracts to entice customers to participate are all relevant questions. This research stream solved various  problems in this domain.

In the final mode, EVs were assumed to have V2H or V2G capabilities. By being able to defer their load in time, and even to inject power back into the home in V2H mode, or even all the way up into the grid in V2G mode, EVs can create a new stream of services and products that can be traded at different levels of the electricity supply chain. These services embody: load shifting, voluntary reserve capacity and frequency regulation services. In this research stream, these new streams of services were explored at the various stages of electricity supply chain. Their use in support of the optimal operation of the grids was investigated not only to operate the system in an efficient manner, but also to allow the further penetration of renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind.  Moreover, how to recompense PEV owners suitably for these services (especially considering issues such as loss of battery life through charging and discharging) was considered.

The societal benefit from this project is significant. While charginf of EVs will be a plug-and-charge action for the EV owners, the most efficient timings, and rates for this charging process will result not only in a as-cheap-as-possible charging process for the EV owner, but also in the most efficient load accommodation from the system perspective. Also, these algorithms will enable a further penetration of renewable energy sources into the power system, making the electricity as “green” and environmentally friendly as possible. The algorithms proposed in this project, will also provide system operators with tools that will enable them to operate the grid in a more efficient manner, increasing the reliability and quality of supply to its customers. The emerging focus in the project on the privacy and truthfulness in the coordination of electric vehicle charging has the potential to help resolve the public’s perceived concerns in sharing data with the coordinators for the management of load-side control mechanisms. Finally, business models for commercial charging stations in various modes - monopoly, oligopoly, and perfect competition - have been developed. This is a new business model that will create jobs and enterprenuership opportunities in the near future. Many graduate and undergraduate students have been trained by working on this project. New curriculum and lab materials have also been developed to integrate the research into education and training of students.
